member.name: T:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.OceanOpticsOmniInterface
member.summary: This class creates a communication interface to provide a gateway to OceanOptics spectrophotometers via the OmniDriver. A separate interface class was developed as you can only have ONE instance of the Wrapper class instantiated in your EXE. Therefore if there are multiple spectrophotometers they must ALL use the SAME communication interface instance.

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.Init(System.UInt16,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the Pcan USB Control.
member.remarks:
This function make the following: - Activate a Hardware - Make a Register Test of 82C200/SJA1000 - Allocate a Send buffer and a Hardware handle - Programs the configuration of the transmit/receive driver - Set the Baudrate register - Set the Controller in RESET condition
If CANMsgType=0 ---> ID 11Bit If CANMsgType=1 ---> ID 11/29Bit
Possible Errors: NOVXD ILLHW REGTEST RESOURCE
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.Close
member.summary:
This function terminate and release the configured hardware and all. allocated resources
Possible Errors: NOVXD
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.Status
member.summary:
This function request the current status of the hardware (b.e. BUS-OFF)
Possible Errors: NOVXD BUSOFF BUSHEAVY OVERRUN
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.Write(Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.TPCANMsg@)
member.summary:
This function Place a CAN message into the Transmit Queue of the CAN Hardware
Possible Errors: NOVXD RESOURCE BUSOFF QXMTFULL
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.Read(Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.TPCANMsg@)
member.summary:
This function get the next message or the next error from the Receive Queue of the CAN Hardware. REMARK: - Check always the type of the received Message (MSGTYPE_STANDARD,MSGTYPE_RTR, MSGTYPE_EXTENDED,MSGTYPE_STATUS) - The function will return ERR_OK always that you receive a CAN message successfully although if the messages is a MSGTYPE_STATUS message. - When a MSGTYPE_STATUS mesasge is got, the ID and Length information of the message will be treated as indefined values. Actually information of the received message should be interpreted using the first 4 data bytes as follow:
Data0 Data1 Data2 Data3 Kind of Error 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x02 CAN_ERR_OVERRUN 0x0002 CAN Controller was read to late 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x04 CAN_ERR_BUSLIGHT 0x0004 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (96) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x08 CAN_ERR_BUSHEAVY 0x0008 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (128) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x10 CAN_ERR_BUSOFF 0x0010 Bus Error: Can Controller went "Bus-Off" - If a CAN_ERR_BUSOFF status message is received, the CAN Controller must to be initialized again using the Init() function. Otherwise, will be not possible to send/receive more messages. - The message will be written to 'msgbuff'.
Possible Errors: NOVXD QRCVEMPTY
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.ReadEx(Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.TPCANMsg@,Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.TPCANTimestamp@)
member.summary:
This function get the next message or the next error from the Receive Queue of the CAN Hardware and the time when the message arrived. REMARK: - Check always the type of the received Message (MSGTYPE_STANDARD,MSGTYPE_RTR, MSGTYPE_EXTENDED,MSGTYPE_STATUS) - The function will return ERR_OK always that you receive a CAN message successfully although if the messages is a MSGTYPE_STATUS message. - When a MSGTYPE_STATUS mesasge is got, the ID and Length information of the message will be treated as indefined values. Actually information of the received message should be interpreted using the first 4 data bytes as follow: * Data0 Data1 Data2 Data3 Kind of Error 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x02 CAN_ERR_OVERRUN 0x0002 CAN Controller was read to late 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x04 CAN_ERR_BUSLIGHT 0x0004 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (96) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x08 CAN_ERR_BUSHEAVY 0x0008 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (128) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x10 CAN_ERR_BUSOFF 0x0010 Bus Error: Can Controller went "Bus-Off" - If a CAN_ERR_BUSOFF status message is received, the CAN Controller must to be initialized again using the Init() function. Otherwise, will be not possible to send/receive more messages. - The message will be written to 'msgbuff'. Since Version 2.x the Ext. Version is available - new Parameter: - Receive timestamp
Possible Errors: NOVXD QRCVEMPTY
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.ResetClient
member.summary:
This function delete the both queues (Transmit,Receive) of the CAN Controller using a RESET
Possible Errors: ERR_ILLCLIENT ERR_NOVXD
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.MsgFilter(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
This function set the receive message filter of the CAN Controller. REMARK: - A quick register of all messages is possible using the parameters FromID and ToID = 0 - Every call of this function maybe cause an extention of the receive filter of the CAN controller, which one can go briefly to RESET - New in Ver 2.x: * Standard frames will be put it down in the acc_mask/code as Bits 28..13 * Hardware driver for 82C200 must to be moved to Bits 10..0 again! WARNING: It is not guaranteed to receive ONLY the registered messages.
Possible Errors: NOVXD ILLCLIENT ILLNET REGTEST
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsbControl.ResetFilter
member.summary:
This function close completely the Message Filter of the Hardware.
They will be no more messages received.
Possible Errors: NOVXD
member.returns: The result

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.ReadEx(Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.TCLightMsg@,Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.TCLightTimestamp@)
member.summary: PCANLight ReadEx function This function get the next message or the next error from the Receive Queue of the CAN Hardware and the time when the message arrived. REMARK: - Check always the type of the received Message (MSGTYPE_STANDARD,MSGTYPE_RTR, MSGTYPE_EXTENDED,MSGTYPE_STATUS) - The function will return ERR_OK always that you receive a CAN message successfully although if the messages is a MSGTYPE_STATUS message. - When a MSGTYPE_STATUS mesasge is got, the ID and Length information of the message will be treated as indefined values. Actually information of the received message should be interpreted using the first 4 data bytes as follow: * Data0 Data1 Data2 Data3 Kind of Error 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x02 CAN_ERR_OVERRUN 0x0002 CAN Controller was read to late 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x04 CAN_ERR_BUSLIGHT 0x0004 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (96) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x08 CAN_ERR_BUSHEAVY 0x0008 Bus Error: An error counter limit reached (128) 0x00 0x00 0x00 0x10 CAN_ERR_BUSOFF 0x0010 Bus Error: Can Controller went "Bus-Off" - If a CAN_ERR_BUSOFF status message is received, the CAN Controller must to be initialized again using the Init() function. Otherwise, will be not possible to send/receive more messages.
member.param: The TCLightMsg structure to store the CAN message
The TCLightTimestamp structure to store the timestamp of the CAN message
member.returns: A CANResult value - Error/status of the hardware after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.VersionInfo(System.String@)
member.summary: PCANLight VersionInfo function This function get the Version and copyright of the hardware as text (max. 255 characters)
member.param: String variable to return the hardware information
member.returns: A CANResult value - Error/status of the hardware after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.DllVersionInfo(System.String@)
member.summary: PCANLight DllVersionInfo function This function get the Version information of the used PCAN-Light DLL. (max. 255 characters)
member.param: String buffer to return the DLL information
member.returns: A CANResult value generated after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.ResetClient
member.summary: PCANLight ResetClient function This function delete the both queues (Transmit,Receive) of the CAN Controller using a RESET
member.returns: A CANResult value - Error/status of the hardware after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.MsgFilter(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.MsgTypes)
member.summary: PCANLigth MsgFilter function This function set the receive message filter of the CAN Controller. REMARK: - A quick register of all messages is possible using the parameters From and To as 0 - Every call of this function maybe cause an extention of the receive filter of the CAN controller, which one can go briefly to RESET - New in Ver 2.x: * Standard frames will be put it down in the acc_mask/code as Bits 28..13 * Hardware driver for 82C200 must to be moved to Bits 10..0 again! WARNING: It is not guaranteed to receive ONLY the registered messages.
member.param: First/Start Message ID - It muss be smaller than the "To" parameter
Last/Finish Message ID - It muss be bigger than the "From" parameter
Kind of Frame - Standard or Extended
member.returns: A CANResult value - Error/status of the hardware after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Interfaces.PeakCAN.PCanUsb.ResetFilter
member.summary: PCANLigth ResetFilter function This function close completely the Message Filter of the Hardware. They will be no more messages received.
member.returns: A CANResult value - Error/status of the hardware after execute the function

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Connection.SendPacket(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Byte[][])
member.summary: Sends a packet to the connected device and expects to receive a reply back from it. If packet STX/ETX characters have been set then only replies that fit within that structure will be checked and returned. This method IS thread safe.
member.param: The packet data to transmit to the connected device
The timeout in milliseconds to wait for a response from the device. A timeout of less than or equal to 0 will NOT wait for a reply.
An array of valid reply strings from the device. The reply will be checked to see if it CONTAINS any one of the specified responses.
member.returns: The reply received from the device

member.name: M:Labman.Communication.Connection.SendAndReceivePacket(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a packet to the connected device and expects to receive a reply back from it. member.param: The packet data to transmit to the connected device

member.summary: Sends a packet to the connected device and expects to receive a reply back from it. If packet STX/ETX characters have been set then only replies that fit within that structure will be checked and returned. This method IS thread safe.

The timeout in milliseconds to wait for a response from the device
An array of valid reply strings from the device. The reply will be checked to see if it CONTAINS any one of the specified responses.

member.summary: Changes the stability setting of the balance (Value Release in Mettler manual)

member.summary: Sets the enabled state of the keypad
member.param: The state you wish to set the keypad to

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Balances.MettlerBalance.SetWeighingParameters(Labman.Hardware.Balances.Balance.StabilitySetting)
member.summary: Sets the balance waighing parameters based on the stability setting. This method used to be used to set the stability within Merlin, but was depriceated in favour of a more direct approach.
member.remarks:
The balance stability setting should be tailored to the environment in which the balance will be operating along with the reliability of the weight you require. All but one of the weighing parameters are defaulted as below:
VIBRATION ADAPTER = 2 1=Low - Rapid stabilization, unstable if disturbances appear. Use for stable environments. 2=Medium -Average 3=High - Slow stabilization, use in unstable environments
WEIGHIING PROCESS ADAPTOR = 3 0=AdaptOff - Weight values have a fixed relation to the weight change with respect to time. Suitable for controlled dispensing systems. 1=Fill - Display reacts quickly to small weight changes. Suitable for uncontrolled dispensing systems. 2=Normal - Rapid/Coarse dispensing systems 3=Check - Highly non-linear, load dependant behaivour. Suitable for rapid weight acquisition with very stable final value.
REPROSET - Defined by the stability setting (off is ignored) 0=Off - only 2 consecutive values are compared 1=Std - 3 readings compared 2=Good - 5 readings compared 3=Excellent - 7 readings compared 4=Best - 9 readings compared
WEIGHT UNIT 1 = 0 (g) 0=g , 1=kg , 2=t , 3=lb , 4=oz , 5=ozt , 6=GN , 7=dwt , 8=ct , 9=mg , 10=ug , 11=mo , 12=msg
AUTOZERO = 1 (ON) 0=off 1=on
READABILITY = 1 (10d) 0=1d - max accuracy 1=10d - faster
WEIGH UNIT 2 = 0 (g) 0=g , 1=kg , 2=t , 3=lb , 4=oz , 5=ozt , 6=GN , 7=dwt , 8=ct , 9=mg , 10=ug , 11=mo , 12=msg
PRESET TARE = 0 (off) 0=off, 1=on
ACTIVATE FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 0 (off) 0=off, 1=on
DECIMAL PLACES OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 2 (not DP of balance!)
FACTOR OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 1 (ignore)
NAME OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 0 (ignore)
MENU LANGUAGE = 0 (English) 0=English, 1=German, 2=French, 3=Spanish, 4=Italian, 5=Russian, 6=Japanese
member.param: The setting for the stability of the balance

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.DeviceSettings.BalanceSettings
member.summary: This class defines all of the settings that are relevant for balances

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.DeviceSettings.BalanceSettings.CommunicationSettings
member.summary: The communications settings to use for this balance

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.DeviceSettings.BalanceSettings.StableWeightTimeout
member.summary: Time out in seconds used when getting a stable weight from the balance
member.remarks: The stable weight timeout defaults to 90s (1.5 minutes) unless you set it otherwise

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.DeviceSettings.BalanceSettings.ZeroTolerance
member.summary: Tolerance in grams, used when taring the balance
member.remarks: If the zeroweight (where zeroweight = 0 + zero tolerance) is less than the current weight reading on the balance then the zero method will re-attempt the zero until the weight reading falls below zeroweight, or a timeout occurs. This value is defaulted to 0 i.e. the balance reading has to be exactly 0 unless you set it otherwise

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.DeviceSettings.BalanceSettings.PostTareGetWeightPacketTimeout
member.summary: The packet timeout when attempting to get a weight from the balance, only used after a tare in the sartorius module
member.remarks: Sartorius balances require a zero weight from the balance to accept it has tared successfully, the default timeout is 2 seconds. This means we poll the balance continously and get lots of comm errors in log. This timeout allows you to set a time to allow the zero to return without hammering the balance with get weight requests

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.BarcodeReaders.LeuzeDCR200iXmlInterface.AddCodeSymbolToDecoderTable(Labman.Hardware.BarcodeReaders.LeuzeSymbologyType,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32})

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.BarcodeReaders.LeuzeDCR200iXmlInterface.AutoSetupBarcodeReader
member.summary: Runs the barcode reader's Auto Setup routine. This attempts to identify any codes currently presented to the barcode reader and stores the code types in the devices internal codes table. This also sets up illumination and exposure settings. Note that this will clear the known code types table if called regardless of success.
member.returns: A value tuple of the code, symbol type and number of digits in the code detected in the auto setup routine. Returns null if no code is detected.

member.summary: This will initiate a grip. The jaws will move until they encounter a resistance that generates the strength limit as provided. Negative values will perform the same operation in reverse, opening them until resistance is met. A limit of 1-2 Amps should be adequate for most gripping applications. Anything higher may generate excess waste heat.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.CombiPal.CleanUp(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.MotorController.WaitForCompletion,System.Int32)
member.summary: Basically like a homing routine where different options can be enabled.
member.param: Wash station. Used for cleaning the syringe if the syringe is not empty.
If an injector has a valve referenced, the valve is switched to standby position.
All temperatures are set to standby temperature.

The syringe plunger zero position is initialized by moving the plunger down until it is blocked. If the syringe is not empty when CLEANUP is called, before initializing the PAL moves to the waste position that is referenced in the passed Wash Station and ejects the syringe content. Then the syringe is cleaned at the passed Wash Station using the wash stations Clean Cnt for the number of cleaning cycles.
If any stack drawer is open it will be closed.
The injection unit moves to the Home position. This is usually at 0,0,0 but can be moved to any position by changing the object Home.
Whether to wait for the operation
How long to wait for the operation before erroring

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetCellGain
member.summary: Gets the gain applied internally in the device to the temperature compensated mV/V (CMVV) to convert it to the raw cell output (CRAW). (CMVV * Cell Gain) - Cell Offset
member.returns: The current value of CGAI on the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetCellOffset
member.summary: Gets the offset applied internally in the device to the temperature compensated mV/V (CMVV) to convert it to the raw cell output (CRAW). (CMVV * Cell Gain) - Cell Offset
member.returns: The current value of COFS on the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetCellRangeMax
member.summary: Gets the maximum value the raw cell output (CRAW) can be (CMAX). Measurements of CRAW higher than this value will be clamped to this value and a warning flag will be raised when the devices status is queried. Usually this will be in N or kN.
member.returns: The current value of CMAX on the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetCellRangeMin
member.summary: Gets the minimum value the raw cell output (CRAW) can be (CMIN). Measurements of CRAW lower than this value will be clamped to this value and a warning flag will be raised when the devices status is queried.
member.returns: The current value of CMIN on the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetFirmwareVersion

member.returns: The firmware version of the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetSerialNumber
member.summary: Gets the serial number of the device. The serial number is determined by two int parameters on the device with a calculation which converts them into the overall serial number. The calculation implemented can be found in the manual for the DSC device.
member.returns: The serial number of the device.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetSystemGain

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetSystemOffset

member.returns: The system offset (SOFS)

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.GetSystemOutputRate
member.summary: Gets the output rate of the device. This is the frequency of data capture. Internally the device is always sampling at a high frequency (4.8Khz) and uses this output rate to determine how much averaging should be done.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.SwitchOutput(Labman.Hardware.IODevices.IODevice.OutputState)

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.DscLoadCellConverterAsciiCommandSet.Zero
member.summary: Zeros the main system output (SYS and therefore SOUT) by taking the raw system value (SRAW) and setting the system zero (SZ) to it. SRAW - SZ WARNING: This writes the zero offset to the devices EEPROM. Calling this excessively (every test for example) will cause the EEPROM to wear out. Consider using a software based zeroing technique and reserve the usage of this zero call for calibration.

member.summary: Basically like a homing routine where different options can be enabled.
member.param: Wash station. Used for cleaning the syringe if the syringe is not empty.
If an injector has a valve referenced, the valve is switched to standby position.
All temperatures are set to standby temperature.

The syringe plunger zero position is initialized by moving the plunger down until it is blocked. If the syringe is not empty when CLEANUP is called, before initializing the PAL moves to the waste position that is referenced in the passed Wash Station and ejects the syringe content. Then the syringe is cleaned at the passed Wash Station using the wash stations Clean Cnt for the number of cleaning cycles.
If any stack drawer is open it will be closed.
The injection unit moves to the Home position. This is usually at 0,0,0 but can be moved to any position by changing the object Home.
Whether to wait for the operation
How long to wait for the operation before erroring

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Instruments.MettlerPowderScale.SetWeighingParameters(Labman.Hardware.Instruments.MettlerPowderScale.StabilitySetting)
member.summary: Sets the balance waighing parameters based on the stability setting. This method used to be used to set the stability within Merlin, but was depriceated in favour of a more direct approach.
member.remarks:
The balance stability setting should be tailored to the environment in which the balance will be operating along with the reliability of the weight you require. All but one of the weighing parameters are defaulted as below:
VIBRATION ADAPTER = 2 1=Low - Rapid stabilization, unstable if disturbances appear. Use for stable environments. 2=Medium -Average 3=High - Slow stabilization, use in unstable environments
WEIGHIING PROCESS ADAPTOR = 3 0=AdaptOff - Weight values have a fixed relation to the weight change with respect to time. Suitable for controlled dispensing systems. 1=Fill - Display reacts quickly to small weight changes. Suitable for uncontrolled dispensing systems. 2=Normal - Rapid/Coarse dispensing systems 3=Check - Highly non-linear, load dependant behaivour. Suitable for rapid weight acquisition with very stable final value.
REPROSET - Defined by the stability setting (off is ignored) 0=Off - only 2 consecutive values are compared 1=Std - 3 readings compared 2=Good - 5 readings compared 3=Excellent - 7 readings compared 4=Best - 9 readings compared
WEIGHT UNIT 1 = 0 (g) 0=g , 1=kg , 2=t , 3=lb , 4=oz , 5=ozt , 6=GN , 7=dwt , 8=ct , 9=mg , 10=ug , 11=mo , 12=msg
AUTOZERO = 1 (ON) 0=off 1=on
READABILITY = 1 (10d) 0=1d - max accuracy 1=10d - faster
WEIGH UNIT 2 = 0 (g) 0=g , 1=kg , 2=t , 3=lb , 4=oz , 5=ozt , 6=GN , 7=dwt , 8=ct , 9=mg , 10=ug , 11=mo , 12=msg
PRESET TARE = 0 (off) 0=off, 1=on
ACTIVATE FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 0 (off) 0=off, 1=on
DECIMAL PLACES OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 2 (not DP of balance!)
FACTOR OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 1 (ignore)
NAME OF FREE PROGRAMMABLE UNIT = 0 (ignore)
MENU LANGUAGE = 0 (English) 0=English, 1=German, 2=French, 3=Spanish, 4=Italian, 5=Russian, 6=Japanese
member.param: The setting for the stability of the balance

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.CentrifugeCameras.CentrifugeCamera1Point
member.summary:
Implementation of a centrifugecamera pair that uses a single marker to track the angle of the centrifuge
NOTE - Since it isn't a real piece of hardware, it doesn't necessarily require simulation mode, provided the camera simulation is valid however, the simulate flag will provide random angles if the images aren't in place if the flag is set and the system is in simulation mode

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.CentrifugeCameras.CentrifugeCamera1Point.Simulate
member.summary: When used in conjunction with Baseclass simulation mode, will return random numbers to remove the need to simulate the camera

member.summary: Since this isn't a real piece of hardware, initialisation isn't neccessary

member.summary: Nothing really to dispose of, all resources should be disposed of after use to preserve memory

member.summary: Gets the angle of the centrifuge
member.returns: The abosulte angle of the centrifuge

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MicrowaveDigesters.MicrowaveDigesterMethod.Automation
member.summary:
Method automation: 35ML = 0 10ML = 1 (uses 10ML APD Clampdown Pressure Limit) CrimpCap = 3 (Also, see below)
New values for Automation10ml Bit 0 = 10mL Bit 1 = CrimpCap Bit 2 = Quartz Vessel Bit 3 = Teflon Liner New Value for Easy Prep Vessel (bits 0 through 3 must be zero) Bit 4 = Easy Prep Vessel Method (0x10) Bit 5 = White bit for Teflon Liner (0x20) so 44 is Quartz with White Teflon Liner, and 40 is Pyrex White Teflon Liner Bit 6 is Dual Control (T + P) for White Liner only, else implies Temperature Control only

member.summary: The drive flags determine the current drive state

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SCONBits
member.summary: Byte 1: SCON (Status condition)

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SPOSBits
member.summary: Byte 2: SPOS (Status position)

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits
member.summary: Byte 3: SDIR (Status direct)

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.ABS
member.summary: Bit 0 - Absolute/Relative = 1: Setpoint value is relative to last setpoint value. = 0: Setpoint value is absolute.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.COM1
member.summary: Bit 1 + 2 - Control Mode Feedback No. | Com 2 | Com 1 | Control mode 0 | 0 | 0 | Positioning mode 1 | 0 | 1 | Power mode(torque, current) 2 | 1 | 0 | Speed mode(rotational speed) 3 | 1 | 1 | Reserved

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.B3
member.summary: Bit 3 Reserved, must be at 0.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.VLIM
member.summary: Bit 5 - Velocity Limit Reached = 1: Speed limit reached = 0: Speed limit not reached

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.XLIM
member.summary: Bit 6 - Stroke Limit Reached = 1: Stroke limit reached = 0: Stroke limit not reached

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.SDIRBits.B6
member.summary: Bit 6 + 7 Reserved, must be at 0.

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CCONBits
member.summary: Byte 1: CCON (Control condition)

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CPOSBits
member.summary: Byte 2: CPOS (Control position)

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits
member.summary: Byte 3: CDIR (Control direct)

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits.ABS
member.summary: Bit 0 - Absolute/Relative = 1: Setpoint value is relative to last setpoint value. = 0: Setpoint value is absolute. Considered only in positioning mode(COM1/2 = 00).

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits.COM1
member.summary: Bit 1 + 2 - Control Mode No. | Com 2 | Com 1 | Control mode 0 | 0 | 0 | Positioning mode 1 | 0 | 1 | Power mode(torque, current) 2 | 1 | 0 | Speed mode(rotational speed) 3 | 1 | 1 | Reserved

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits.B3
member.summary: Bit 3 + 4 Reserved, must be at 0.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits.XLIM
member.summary: Bit 5 - Stroke Limit Inactive = 1: Stroke monitoring not active = 0: Stroke monitoring active Considered only with force mode or speed mode (COM1/2 = 01 or 10)

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.FestoFHPPMotorController.DriveFlags.CDIRBits.B6
member.summary: Bit 6 + 7 Reserved, must be at 0.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.LabmanLMCMotorController.SetMacAddress(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the boards MAC address. Actual physical address change will occur when the board next reboots. This must be exactly 6 bytes. Note: This function should only be called by the Labman LMC board flashing utility baring rare exceptions. This tool generates and stores these address in a Labman internal database. It is key that these addresses are unique from board to board. Otherwise unusual network behavior may occur. Additionally, MAC addresses must start with Labman's OUI which identifies the LMA board as being a registered Labman network device. This OUI is provided by the IEEE.
member.param: The bytes of the mac address (should be exactly 6 bytes) to set.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.LabmanLMCMotorController.SetMacAddress(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the boards MAC address. Actual physical address change will occur when the board next reboots. This must be exactly 6 bytes. Note: This function should only be called by the Labman LMC board flashing utility baring rare exceptions. This tool generates and stores these address in a Labman internal database. It is key that these addresses are unique from board to board. Otherwise unusual network behavior may occur. Additionally, MAC addresses must start with Labman's OUI which identifies the LMA board as being a registered Labman network device. This OUI is provided by the IEEE.
member.param: The mac address to set in string form. The string is parsed using PhysicalAddress.Parse method (System.Net.NetworkingInfomation). Recommended string format example: 02-00-DE-AD-BE-12 As per the other notes, this MAC address must be exactly 6 bytes.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.LabmanLMCMotorController.SetMacAddress(System.Net.NetworkInformation.PhysicalAddress)
member.summary: Sets the boards MAC address. Actual physical address change will occur when the board next reboots. This must be exactly 6 bytes. Note: This function should only be called by the Labman LMC board flashing utility baring rare exceptions. This tool generates and stores these address in a Labman internal database. It is key that these addresses are unique from board to board. Otherwise unusual network behavior may occur. Additionally, MAC addresses must start with Labman's OUI which identifies the LMA board as being a registered Labman network device. This OUI is provided by the IEEE.
member.param: The physical MAC address to set.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.LabmanLMCMotorController.SetSocketInactivityTimeout(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Sets the boards socket inactivity timeout. This is how long the board will keep a TCP socket open for before finalizing the connection if no commands are received. The timer is reset when a valid command is received.
member.param: The timeout. Note that this must be less than 2,147,483,647 seconds (31 bits). Which is 68 years.... Set this to 0 to disable the inactivity timeout.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.InitializeGripper(System.Int32)
member.summary: The 'InitMode' parameter specifies the initialization modes. Under normal init, the function checks for object presence prior to init and if object is detected, the function does not perform an initialization. The function also does not init if the CAM is in an intermediate position (neither fully closed nor opened). Alternative init does not perform the checking. Closed or open specifies the gripper fingers position after the initialization is performed. The default 'InitMode' is 0, normal init closed.
member.param: The axis index the gripper is attached to.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.InitializeGripper(System.Int32,Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.GripperInitMode)
member.summary: The parameter specifies the initialization modes. Under normal init, the function checks for object presence prior to init and if object is detected, the function does not perform an initialization. The function also does not init if the CAM is in an intermediate position (neither fully closed nor opened). Alternative init does not perform the checking. Closed or open specifies the gripper fingers position after the initialization is performed. The default is 0, normal init closed.
member.param: The axis index the gripper is attached to.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.CheckForExit(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves the tip out of the liquid starting from the current position and checks for an exit signal.
member.param: The ID of the z axis the ADP is mounted to.
The retract speed. Valid values are from 1 to 150 mm/s.
The travel distance. Valid values are from 1 to 100 mm.
The acceptance limit for a successful exit signal check. Valid values are from 0 to 50 mm.
The sensitivity in increments during exit search. Valid values are from 3 (highest sensitivity) to 120 (lowest sensitivity).

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.DetectLiquid(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TecanOmniAPIMotorController.DetectionMethod,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs liquid detection using the cLLD. When the DetectLiquid command is issued, the Z-drive moves to the using the default move parameters, and starts searching for liquid from that position using the speed and search sensitivity specified by LLDSearchSpeed and . When the liquid surface is detected by the tip, the Z-move immediately stops. If performing a single detection, the detection is considered successful if the detection position minus the given is higher than or equal to the value of . If performing a double detection, the tip retracts the default distance defined by Set,LLDRetractDist using the given search speed (LLDSearchSpeed) and starts the liquid search again. It is considered successful if the second detection position minus the given is higher than or equal to the value of , and the difference between the two detection positions is less than or equal to the acceptance window. The acceptance window is defined by the Set,LLDAcceptanceWindow command. If the liquid detection is successful, a subsequent down move is performed to submerge the tip, using the speed specified by LLDSearchSpeed. An error is generated if the limit specified in is reached without detecting the liquid. This command replies with an error code 0 (no error) if all Z-drives executed successfully; otherwise, the last error encountered is returned.
member.param: The ID of the z axis the ADP is mounted to.
Start position for the liquid search. Valid values are from RangeLow to RangeHigh. If you are using disposable tips, the highest position should be no higher than RangeHigh 10 mm.

The position limit to search for liquid, starting from the position given in StartPos. If liquid is not found during this entire travel, an error is returned. Valid values are from StartPos to RangeLow.
The submerge distance after successful detection. Valid values are from 0 to 100 mm.
The sensitivity in increments during liquid search. Valid values are from 3 (highest sensitivity) to 120 (lowest sensitivity).
Retract to start position on error.

member.param: Indication of weather to wait for the home to complete or not.
The time to spend waiting for the home to complete before throwing an exception.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController1160.SetEncoderPosition(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the encoder position on the board. For the 1160, there are two axis parameters indicating encoder position: One for the internal StepOSense encoder and another for the externally wired encoder. We will usually use the external encoder. To handle this, this method looks at _encoderModes field for the encoder mode of this axis and sets the relevant axis parameter accordingly.
member.param: The axis to set the encoder position for.
The position to set this parameter to.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController1160.GetEncoderPosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the encoder position on the board. For the 1160, there are two axis parameters indicating encoder position: One for the internal StepOSense encoder and another for the externally wired encoder. We will usually use the external encoder. To handle this, this method looks at _encoderModes field for the encoder mode of this axis and gets the relevant axis parameter accordingly.
member.param: The axis to get the encoder position for.
member.returns: The current encoder position for the specified axis.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController1160.SetEncoderMode(System.Int32,Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllerBase.EncoderModes)
member.summary: Sets the devices encoder mode. For the 1160, there are two axis parameters indicating encoder position: One for the internal StepOSense encoder and another for the externally wired encoder. We will usually use the external encoder. To handle this, this method looks at _encoderModes field for the encoder mode of this axis and gets the relevant axis parameter accordingly.
member.param: The axis to set the encoder mode for
The mode to set the encoder mode to.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController1160.GetEncoderMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the configured encoder mode for a particular axis. For the 1160, there are two axis parameters indicating encoder position: One for the internal StepOSense encoder and another for the externally wired encoder. We will usually use the external encoder. To handle this, this method looks at _encoderModes field for the encoder mode of this axis and gets the relevant axis parameter accordingly.
member.param: The axis to get the encoder mode of.
member.returns: The encoder mode configured for the passed axis.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MaximumPositioningSpeed

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.RightLimitSwitchDisable
member.summary: 12. Right limit switch enable/polarity. 0/1/2. RW. 0 = switch deactivated, 1 = switch active, motor will stop if input is low, 2 = switch active, motor will stop if input is high

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.LeftLimitSwitchDisable
member.summary: 13. Left limit switch enable/polarity. 0/1/2. RW. 0 = switch deactivated, 1 = switch active, motor will stop if input is low, 2 = switch active, motor will stop if input is high

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.RampType
member.summary: 14. Ramp type. 0/1. RW. Selects the type of ramp to be used. 0 = trapezoidal ramp. 1 = S-shaped ramp.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.StartVelocity
member.summary: 15. Start velocity. 0 to 16777215 pps. RW. Initial velocity at motion start for trapezoidal ramps.

member.summary: 16. Start acceleration. 0 to 2147483647 pps2. RW. Initial acceleration at motion start of trapezoidal ramps. Will be changed to maximum acceleration ( ) as soon as the break velocity has been reached

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MaximumDeceleration
member.summary: 17. Maximum deceleration. 0 to 2147483647 pps2. RW. Maximum deceleration for trapezoidal ramps. May be set to the same value as the maximum acceleration ( , but can also be set to a different value.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.BreakVelocity

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.FinalDeceleration
member.summary: 19. Final deceleration. 0 to 2147483647 pps2. RW. Deceleration used as soon as the actual velocity has fallen below

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.StopVelocity
member.summary: 20. Stop velocity. 0 to 16777215 pps. RW. Velocity when target position has been reached andmotion stops in trapezoidal ramps.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.StopDeceleration
member.summary: 21. Stop deceleration. 0 to 2147483647 pps2. RW. Deceleration value if stop switches or virtual stops are used with soft ramps. A value that's not 0 will generate an automatic linear ramp when a stop switch is hit or a virtual stop has been reached.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.VirtualStopLeft
member.summary: 26. Virtual stop left. +-2147483647 steps. RW. Virtual stop position when motor is moving in negative direction.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.VirtualStopRight
member.summary: 27. Virtual stop right. +-2147483647 steps. RW. Virtual stop position when motor is moving in positive direction.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.VirtualStopEnable
member.summary: 28. Virtual stop enable. 0-3. RW. 0 = both virtual stop disabled, 1 = virtual stop left enable, 2 = virtual stop right enable, 3 = both virtual stop enabled.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.VirtualStopMode
member.summary: 29. Virtual stop mode. 0-2. RW. 0 = use normal ramp deceleration settings, 1 = use hard stop, 2 = use stop deceleration ( ).

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.SwapStopSwitches
member.summary: 33. Swap stop switches. 0/1. RW. 1 = Use right stop switch for negative direction and left stop switch for positive direction.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.EnableSoftStop
member.summary: 34. Enable soft stop. 0/1. RW. 0 = use hard stop at stop switches, 1 = use deceleration ramp ( ) at stop switches.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.TorqueMode
member.summary: 50. Torque mode. +-255. RW. Writing to this parameter will run the motor in torque mode.This only works in closed loop mode.Any other motion command (MST, ROL, ROR, MVP) stops the torque mode.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.RelativePositioningOption
member.summary: 127. Relative positioning option. 0/1. RW

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ClosedLoopFlag
member.summary: 129. Closed loop flag. 0/1. RW. 0 = closed loop off, 1 = closed loop on. After switching on closed loop, please wait until is 1 before executing any motion commands.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MeasuredSpeed
member.summary: 131. Measuered speed. +-2147483647 pps. R. Speed measured using the encoder.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.CurrentMeasuredSpeed
member.summary: 132. Current measuered speed. +-2147483647 pps. R. Speed measured using the encoder without averaging.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ClosedLoopInitFlag
member.summary: 133. Closed loop initialised flag. 0/1. RW. 0 = initialisation not finished yet, 1 = closed loop initialistaion finished.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.PositioningWindow
member.summary: 134. Positioning window. 0 to 2147483647 steps. RW. Maximum deviation for target reached flag to be set.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MicrostepResolution
member.summary: 140. Microstep resolution. 0 to 8. RW. 0 = full step, 1 = half step, 2 = 4 microsteps, 3 = 8 microsteps, 4 = 16 microsteps, 5 = 32 microsteps, 6 = 64 microsteps, 7 = 128 microsteps, 8 = 256 microsteps. Always leave at 8 (256 microsteps) when using closed loop operation!

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ReferenceSearchMode
member.summary: 193. Reference search mode. See remarks. RW
member.remarks: 1 = Search left stop switch only. 2 = Search right stop switch, then search left stop switch. 3 = Search right stop switch, then search left stop switch from both sides. 4 = Search left stop switch from both sides. 5 = Search home switch in negative direction, reverse the direction when left stop switch reached. 6 = Search home switch in positive direction, reverse the direction when right stop switch reached. 7 = Search home switch in positive direction, ignore end switches. 8 = Search home switch in negative direction, ignore end switches. Additional functions: Add 128 to a mode value for inverting the home switch (can be used with mode 5 to 8). Add 64 to a mode for searching the right instead of the left reference switch (can be used with mode 1 to 4).

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ReferenceSearchSpeed
member.summary: 194. Reference search speed. 0 to 16777215 steps/s. RW

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ReferenceSwitchSpeed
member.summary: 195. Reference switch speed. 0 to 16777215 steps/s. RW

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.BoostCurrent
member.summary: 200. Boost current. 0 to 255. RW. Current used for acceleration and deceleration phases. If set to 0, the same current as set by will be used. Same scaling as with .

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.FullStepResolution
member.summary: 202. Motor full step resolution. 0 to 65535 full steps / round. RW. Full step resolution of the motor (Default 200).

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.Freewheeling
member.summary: 204. Freewheeling mode. 0 to 3 ms. RW. Stand still option when the is set to zero. 0 = normal operation, 1 = freewheeling, 2 = coil shorted using low side drivers, 3 = coil shorted using high side drivers

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.EncoderPrescaler
member.summary: 210. Encoder prescaler. +-65535. RW. Encoder counts per round. Setting this to a negative value reverses the encoder counting direction.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MaximumEncoderDeviation
member.summary: 212. Maximum encoder deviation. 0 to 65535 2147483647 steps. RW

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.MaxVelocityDeviation
member.summary: 213. Group index. 0 to 2147483647 steps. RW. The motor will be stopped when the desired speed and the real speed differ more than this value. Setting the value to 0 turns off this function.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.PowderDownDelay
member.summary: 214. Power down delay. 0 to 65535 x 10 ms. RW. Standard value is 200 = 2000ms

member.summary: 249. Group index. 0 to 255. RW. All motors on the module which have the same group index will get the same commands when a ROL, ROR, MST, MVP, or RFS is issued for one of these motors. Setting the group index to 0 (default) turns off this feature for the motor.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController3351.AxisParameters3351.ReverseShaft
member.summary: 251. Reverse shaft. 0/1. RW

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController6212.AxisParameters6212.StealthChopPWMGradient
member.summary: Range 0 - 15, Allows the setting of the velocity dependent gradient for PWM amplitude. Setting this to 0 (default) disables stealth chop. Setting this to 1 or greater significantly reduces motor whine / noise but can result in less torque.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorController6212.AxisParameters6212.ReferenceSearchMode
member.summary: 193. Reference search mode. See remarks. RW
member.remarks: 1 = Search left stop switch only. 2 = Search right stop switch, then search left stop switch. 3 = Search right stop switch, then search left stop switch from both sides. 4 = Search left stop switch from both sides. 5 = Search home switch in negative direction, reverse the direction when left stop switch reached. 6 = Search home switch in positive direction, reverse the direction when right stop switch reached. 7 = Search home switch in positive direction, ignore end switches. 8 = Search home switch in negative direction, ignore end switches. Additional functions: Add 128 to a mode value for inverting the home switch (can be used with mode 5 to 8). Add 64 to a mode for searching the right instead of the left reference switch (can be used with mode 1 to 4).

member.summary: 194. Reference search speed. 0 to 7999774 steps/s. RW

member.summary: 202. Motor full step resolution. 0 to 65535 full steps / round. RW. Full step resolution of the motor (Default 200).

member.summary: 204. Freewheeling mode. 0 to 3 ms. RW. Stand still option when the is set to zero. 0 = normal operation, 1 = freewheeling, 2 = coil shorted using low side drivers, 3 = coil shorted using high side drivers

member.param: The axis index. Needed to extract motor ratio.
The value in board units (usually pps (microsteps per second)).
member.returns: The value in engineering units (mm/s, deg/s etc. Dependant on motor ratio).

member.summary: 207. Extended error flags. Bitmask. R Bit 0: motor has been stopped due to encoder deviation error. Bit 1: motor has been stopped due to motor stall. These two flags are cleared with the next movement command.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.MotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllers.TrinamicMotorControllerBase.AxisParameters.DriveErrorFlags
member.summary: 208. Driver error flags. Bitmask. R. Bits: 0 = stallGuard2 status (1: stall detected), 1 = Overtemperature (1: driver is shut down due to overtemperature), 2 = Overtemperature pre-warning (1: temperature threshold is exceeded), 3 = Short to ground A (1: short condition detected, driver currently shut down), 4 = Short to ground B (1: short condition detected, driver currently shut down), 5 = Open load A (1: no chopper event has happened during the last period with constant coil polarity), 6 = Open load B (1: no chopper event has happened during the last period with constant coil polarity), 7 = Stand still (1: no step pulse occurred during the last 220 clock cycles)

Sequentially swaps pairs of bytes in an array to turn a little endian array of words into a little endian array of bytes
For this use-case the word array is little endian but each word in the array is big endian
Swap is in place (ref) in case of (very) long arrays

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Rheometers.AntonPaar.SendCommandAndReceiveResponse(System.String)
member.summary: Abstracts the sending and receiving of commands and responses to and from the rheometer. Includes response error checking.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Rheometers.AntonPaar.SetupRheometerToReceiveProgram
member.summary: Sets up the rheometers spindle info so that it can receive commands.

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Rheometers.AntonPaar.BuildProgram(Labman.Hardware.Rheometers.RheometerProgramParameters)
member.summary: Generates a rheometer program string from a ProgramParameters object..
member.param: DTO to pass containing the program parameters and settings
member.returns: Command string to be passed to the rheometer
member.remarks:
================================================================================================== The command string is composed out of three parts, Header, Measurement and Ending.
1. Header: The header can be considered as a constant string of the following form: :PROG["Test", TEST[(
2. Measurement: The measurement string is composed out of the following blocks: o NDP Number of data points o DPD Data point duration o A Averaging o V Variable o P Profile o RP Return parameters o SS Steady state + event control options o CV Variable for Continuous Value setting o CP Profile for Continuous Value setting
The blocks are arranged in the following form: o For stepwise(standard) value setting: PART[(NDP, DPD, A), (), (), (), (V[1, P]), (), (),, (RP), (SS), ()]
o For continuous value setting, the blocks are arranged in the following form: PART[(NDP, DPD, A), (CV[1, CP]), (), (), (), (), (),, (RP), (SS), ()]
3. Ending: The Ending is a constant string of the following form: )],EXIT[()],CANC[()]] =============================================================================================

member.name: M:Labman.Hardware.Rheometers.AntonPaar.RunProgram(System.Int32)
member.summary: Runs the current program loaded onto the rheometer if it is ready.
member.param: How long to wait before timing out the rheometer in seconds
member.returns: All strings returned by the rheometer appended together.

member.summary: Parses the data string passed back from the rheometer into a rheometer data points object

The raw string returned by the rheometer after a run
member.returns: The data points extracted

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.RobotArms.MitsubishiRobotArm.XYZABCMove.ContinuousDistance
member.summary: How far away from the position the arm passes. If this is set too small the move will be slower than a non-continuous move. If this is not set, the default will be used which is quite a large cut off

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.RobotArms.MitsubishiRobotArm.XYZABCMove.ContinuousMove
member.summary: Whether the robot moves continuously through positions. This means it does not pass exactly through the position, but it does not stop at each position so is faster. See the "cnt" command in melfa basic V help for more information.
member.value: true if [continuous move]; otherwise, false. Defaults to false.

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.TecanCentrisSyringe
member.summary: Class that controls a single Tecan Syringe
member.remarks: NOTE: This class is basically a copy of the normal class with minor modifications. Several of the functions may not actually work on this type of syringe. It was originally created for SNIf by Dave L, then taken over by Luke P for GRCE, then committed for GRCE by Dave A. It would be good to merge it with the normal TecanSyringe class however, there wasn't time on the project to do so. The PDF for it is in Tech Ref, titled TECAN_OEM_Centris_Manual_30038165B. Compared to the normal class, the differences seem to be: - There is no "Fine Positioning" state, so that function should not be called. - The initialisation commands (Z and Y) interpret the first parameter differently. Instead of a value 1-4 which describes both speed and force, it's just a value 4-25 describing the reset speed. Here, the ResetSyringePlunger function has been modified with a fixed value of 4. The other base ResetSyringePlunger methods may not work and the hard coded 4 could do with being a setting in the TecanCentrisSyringeSettings class. - Because of the differences in ResetSyringePlunger, the initialise method calls the different version of that. - The Centris is able to take aspirate and dispense amounts as volumes in uL as well as number of steps. It internally converts to steps based on the syringe volume. Adding an extra ",1" parameter to such commands tells the device that the value is in uL not steps. This change therefore requires the Aspirate and Dispense methods be duplicated here. - On GRCE we needed the SetValvePosition to turn the opposite direction so have modified that function too. This would probably be better as another parameter on the SetValuePosition command. - There also seems to be a difference between the backlash behaviour of the Centris compared to other Tecans. On GRCE dispense amount issues were encountered where the syringe travel was 11mm incorrect. This was accounted for in process code but it may be possible an better to account for it with the K-value backlash setting.

member.summary: The set of parameters controlling a dispense pulse.

member.name: T:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.TriggerModes
member.summary: The types of trigger mode.

member.name: F:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.TriggerModes.BurstMode
member.summary: A single trigger causes a predefined number of dispense cycles.

member.summary: A single trigger causes one dispense cycle.

member.summary: Multiple dispenses are done continuously for the duration of the trigger pulse.

member.summary: A complex set of cycles, predefined in a scenario, is carried out.

member.summary: A single dispense is done continuously for the duration of the trigger pulse.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.TriggerMode
member.summary: The way triggers cause dispenses.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.RisingTime
member.summary: The time required until the valve is completely opened in 0.01ms units. Max 300ms.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.OpenTime
member.summary: During this phase the valve remains in opened state in 0.1ms units. When < 80%, maximum is 3000ms. When > 80%, maximum is 15ms.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.FallingTime
member.summary: The time required for closing the valve in 0.01ms units. Max 300ms.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.DelayTime
member.summary: The waiting phase between two cycles in 0.1ms units. Max 1000ms.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.NeedleLift
member.summary: The stroke of the tappet as a percentage of it's full value. Min 1%. Between 80-100% the valve works in bipolar mode. The elevated temperature required in this range reduces the average frequency and lifetime of the valve. A needle lift between 70-80 is the recommended range.

member.name: P:Labman.Hardware.Syringes.VermesMicroDispenser.Pulse.Cycles
member.summary: Number of cycles. Min 1, Max 32000.

member.name: T:Labman.UserInterface.AttachedProperties.Visibility
member.summary: Attached properties concerning the ability of View objects to inform their ViewModels of their visibility

member.name: F:Labman.UserInterface.AttachedProperties.Visibility._viewModelReferences
member.summary: A Dictionary of collections of Views. Each ViewModel is a Dictionary key for a collection of object. See the remarks in for more details.

member.name: M:Labman.UserInterface.AttachedProperties.Visibility.GetNotifyOnVisibilityChanged(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets whether this visual element notifies its when its visibility changes. The must be of type .
member.returns: Whether this view publishes notifications to its DataContext when its visibility changes

member.name: M:Labman.UserInterface.AttachedProperties.Visibility.SetNotifyOnVisibilityChanged(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets whether this visual element notifies its when its visibility changes. The must be of type .
member.param: Whether this view publishes notifications to its DataContext when its visibility changes

member.name: F:Labman.UserInterface.AttachedProperties.Visibility.NotifyOnVisibilityChangedProperty
member.summary: Whether this visual element notifies its when its visibility changes. The must be of type .
member.remarks:
When this property is attached to an element and set to "true", it informs that element's DataContext when the element's visibility changes. The detection of visibility changing is done primarily using the property and corresponding event. NOTE: This is independent of property.
As well as using the event, the event must also be subscribed to. There are two situations in which this becomes a factor: 1. If the visual element is a DataTemplate, then when the DataContext is set to null (thus triggerring the removal of the visual element), the event fires after the DataContext is already null. Therefore it would be impossible for the view to inform the ViewModel of the change in visibility. As such the event is used. 2. If the visual element has its DataContext swapped out for another DataContext, the View needs to inform the old ViewModel that it is no longer visibile and inform the new ViewModel that it is visible. Again, the is needed.
Another aspect to the way this property works is that a ViewModel may have multiple View objects displaying it at one time. The job of this property is only to inform the ViewModel if it is visible, not how many View objects are making that the case. Therefore, the behaviour of this property is to tell the ViewModel it is visible when ANY visible Views are attached to it, and to tell the ViewModel that it is not visible when NO visible Views are attached to it. To acheive this, a central collection of ViewModel-View references is maintained. Each ViewModel is used as a key to a collection of Views. The collection represents the currently visible Views attached to a given ViewModel. When the collection is empty, that respective ViewModel is not visible. When the collection is non-empty, the ViewModel is visible.

member.summary: The possible modes of arrangement the supports.

member.name: F:Labman.UserInterface.CustomControls.FixerPanel.FixModes.StretchThenScroll
member.summary: Intended to be used inside a , containing an element that would happily take up infinite horizontal and/or vertical space, but can take up less. For example, a in a will normally not wrap and simply take up as much space as it wants. Content will be forced to stretch or shrink to the parent's size until that size is less than the content's and/or properties, at which point it can scroll. Use the property to dictate in which orientation the child should stretch before scrolling. is not currently implemented.

member.name: F:Labman.UserInterface.CustomControls.FixerPanel.FixModes.StretchWithAlignment
member.summary: For use when it is desired that an element has an or other than Stretch, but the element should stretch up to a maximum size, then align itself. Use the and to dictate in which orientation this arrangement is applied. The child element(s) must have their native and/or properties be Stretch.

member.name: T:Labman.UserInterface.CustomControls.XTextBox
member.summary: Self validating textbox. Bound property must be two-way! Provides automatic conversion and validation to the bound type. Also exposes features like custom conversion, custom validation pre/post conversion, type conversion, stringformat, min/max values, regex. Validation order and datatypes: On screen input (string) => Optional pre-conversion validation (string) => Optional regex (string) => Conversion (validated type) => Optional min/max checking (validated type) => Optional post-conversion validation (validated type) => Optional IValueConverter (bound type) => Binding (bound type).

member.name: F:Labman.UserInterface.CustomControls.XTextBox.TextProperty

member.name: P:Labman.UserInterface.ViewModels.PositionDatabaseViewModel.SelectedItem
member.summary: Middle-man property. When the empty row is selected, the view tries to set the SelectedItem binding to a new object which is not of the correct type. If the bound type was specific, this would cause an exception so the grid is coloured red. Using a bound property of type object allows this but only passes on a useful value. We could avoid this by: Restyling the grid to ignore the validation border, but this is a lot of effort and removes a potentially useful behaviour. Just using this object property without the hard-typed property, but this requires casting everywhere.

member.summary: Set the save button state

member.name: M:Labman.UserInterface.ViewModels.PositionDatabaseViewModel.SavePositionsExecute
member.summary: Synchronises the positions records in the datagrid and the database. This is called when the user switches which row they are looking at, which is used to save any changes. Therefore this does not need to cope with records being removed. Only records being added, or updated.

member.name: T:Labman.UserInterface.RelayCommandAsync
member.summary: A class whose sole purpose is to relay its functionality to other objects by invoking delegates. The command's execution is carried out off the UI thread but awaited, such that the flag is still correct. The default behaviour is that multiple instances of the same command cannot be executed concurrently - while executing, the will return false. However, this behaviour can be disabled with the optional constructors.

member.name: T:Labman.UserInterface.RelayCommandAsync`1
member.summary: A class whose sole purpose is to relay its functionality to other objects by invoking delegates. The command's execution is carried out off the UI thread but awaited, such that the flag is still correct. The default behaviour is that multiple instances of the same command cannot be executed concurrently - while executing, the will return false. However, this behaviour can be disabled with the optional constructors.
member.typeparam: The parameter type for the relay command

member.name: M:Labman.UserInterface.WindowViews.WindowBase.AllowsTransparencyChanged(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Windows.DependencyPropertyChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: Called when the property changes.
member.param: The object on which the changed occurred
member.remarks: The only reason this function exists is so we can coerce the property. However, the constructor requires a property changed callback when using a coerce value callback

member.name: M:Labman.UserInterface.WindowViews.WindowBase.CoerceAllowsTransparency(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Object)
member.summary: Coerces the property based on the value of the .
member.param: The object on which the changed occurred
member.returns: The coerced value for
member.remarks:
Getting the desired behaviour in terms of window resize bars, drop shadows, window states and resize modes is tricky. The desired behaviour is summarised as follows: Unless the window is maximized, we always want a drop shadow. Unless the window is maximized, and when ResizeMode is CanResize[WithGrip] we always want drag bars to resize the edges of the window.
Due to the way a window resizes, especially considering Min/Max Width/Heights, taskbar space and WindowStyle=None, the easiest way to acheive reliable window drag bars to resize a window, is using the as is implemented in Generic.xaml. This also gives us the built-in drop shadow for the window. However, when the ResizeMode is such that no drag bars should be visible, we have to remove the WindowChrome and implement our own drop shadow. This requires AllowsTransparency=true. This was previously acheived in the default style in Generic.xaml and worked fine for existing uses. However, when a window that can resize is created in code, rather than in xaml (e.g. a Popup window using ShowDialog), the values for AllowsTransparency defined in Generic.xaml aren't applied until after Show() or ShowDialog() are called. Because no local value has been defined for AllowsTransparency, when the values defined in Generic.xaml are applied, the property system performs value coercion on the incoming value (whether it be true or false). As part of the value coercion, the .NET code checks whether the window already has a SourceWindow, which, in effect, checks whether the Window has already had Show() or ShowDialog() called, which it has (see Window.CoerceAllowsTransparency, Window.cs, line ~827). As such, even if the incomming value of AllowsTransparency is the same as the current value, an error is thrown because the window has already been shown. When the window is instantiated in xaml, this seems to be avoided, probably because the properties are set before the window is shown, or perhaps because Show()/ShowDialog are not explicitly called.
This all means that we have to ensure the value of AllowsTransparency is set correctly, depending on the value of ResizeMode. Setting one value depending on the value of another is what value coercion is for, so we use that. We also have to ensure the values of ResizeMode and WindowStyle are defaulted to the correct default values, but not in xaml. We do this by overriding their metadata in the static constructor. Note, however, we still have to coerce the AllowsTransparency value as the default value is ignored by value coercion.

member.name: M:Labman.MotionControl.ArmSafeMoveChecks.ProgramHistoryLookupSafeMoveCheck.SafeToMove(System.String)
member.summary: Looks at the last program that was run on the arm, and looks up to see if there's a record of running this combination of programs before. If there's not, the user will be asked whether it's safe to move. The thread will be blocked until user input is given. This method may perform an intermediate move between programs.
member.param: The name of the program attempting to be run on the arm
member.returns: True if it's safe for the arm to move, false otherwise

member.summary: Gets the intemediate program to be run between two programs
member.param: The last program that was run
The program to be run now
member.returns: The name of the intermediate program

member.summary: Asks the user if it's safe to run a program, given the last program that ran. This method will also add a record of the user's response to the database.
member.param: The last program that was run
The program that is to be run now
member.returns: True if its safe to run the program, false otherwise
member.remarks: If the user says that an intermediate move is required, it'll be performed as part of this method

member.summary: Enumeration of possible home types

member.name: P:Labman.MotionControl.ServotronixAxisSettings.StepsPerRev
member.summary: The configured feed constant, which is the measurement distance per one revolution of the output shaft of the gearbox. The feed constant is calculated by the following: feed constant = feed driving shaft revolutions

member.name: P:Labman.MotionControl.ServotronixAxisSettings.PositionWindow
member.summary: The symmetrical range of accepted positions relative to the target_position. If the actual value of the position encoder is within the position window, this target position is considered to reached. If the value of the position_window is 4294967295, the position_window control is switched off.

member.name: P:Labman.MotionControl.ServotronixAxisSettings.PositionWindowTime
member.summary: Indicates the time in milliseconds, during which the actual position within the position_window is measured.

member.name: P:Labman.MotionControl.ServotronixAxisSettings.FollowingError
member.summary: Maximum allowed position error without producing a fault. If the value of the following error window is 4294967295, the following control is disabled.
member.remarks: This object defines the range of tolerated position values symmetrical to the target position. If the position actual value is outside the following error window, a following error occurs. A following error may occur when a drive is blocked, an unreachable profile velocity occurs, or if closed-loop coefficients are wrong.

member.name: P:Labman.MotionControl.ServotronixAxisSettings.ResolverAmplitudeRange
member.summary: The acceptable range of deviation of resolver sine/cosine signals(as a percentage).

member.name: T:Labman.Processes.ProcessBase

member.name: M:Labman.PositionsDatabase.PositionDatabase.ScanPosition(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This function will take an index and scan length and calculate the number of increments in the scan line direction, for the specified index. eg. if you have a rack where the rows go along the x direction, with 10 columns, then passing index=2, scanLength=10 will return 1, which is 1 increment in the x direction.
member.returns: int, the calculated scan position.

member.name: M:Labman.PositionsDatabase.PositionDatabase.ScanLine(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This function will take an index and scan line length and calculate the number of the scan line containing the specified index, eg. if you have a rack where the rows go along the x direction, with 10 columns, then passing Index=12 and ScanLength=10 will return 1, which is 1 increment in the y direction.
member.returns: int, the calculated scan line.

member.name: M:Labman.PositionsDatabase.PositionDatabase.PositionOnCircle(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: This function will take the centre position of a circle and the position of one point on the circle, it will then calculate the position on the circle which is incrementAngle radians counterclockwise of the first position.
member.param: Specifies centre position in x plane.
Specifies centre position in y plane.
Specifies centre position in z plane.
Specifies point on circle in x plane.
Specifies point on circle in y plane.
Specifies point on circle in z plane.
member.returns: Position object containing calculated position.

member.summary: This function calculates a position in a rectangular area from an initial position using specified increments, line increments, line length an index.

Specifies first position in y plane.
Specifies first position in z plane.
member.returns: Position object containing calculated position.

member.param: The authentication class instance to authenticate with

member.name: T:Labman.Security.ApplicationAuthenticators.ComputerHardwareTrialAuthenticator
member.summary:
This class provides an application authentication method that checks the software is running on an approved computer. A computer is uniquely idenified using the CPU, Motherboard and HDD Ids
This class also has an optional trial mode will disable the software after a trial period if not unlocked with a unique hardware id.
NOTE The trial isn't fully safe against the user changing the computer clock. Once the outside of the trial changing clock will have not effect. Until the trial expires the user could keep changing the clock back each day. This trial is designed to work silently in the background until it expires so the user is unaware until it's too late.

member.summary: Authenticate the software

member.name: T:Labman.Security.ApplicationAuthenticators.HASPApplicationAuthenticator
member.summary: Class that implements the HASP application authenticator
member.remarks:
The HASP protection framework provides two methods for protecting your software IP; hardware (HASP HL) and software (HASP SL). This standard module is designed to work with the hardware version of this protection framework.
The framework provides two different methods for protecting your software, they are: 1) Envelope This is the quick + dirty method of protection. It wraps a software executable(s) and/or DLL(s) in and envelope that prevents reverse engineering and requires a HASP HL key to be present in order to operate. This method is used to protect the standard module DLL produced by this standard module. 2) API Extra functions are accessible via the API and this allows you to implement custom protection strategies for your software applications. The strategy employed in this particular module is based upon a GUID key used to unlock the software. The software will be fully functional for a definable period of time after which unless an unlocking GUID key is provided the software will no longer function at all. The GUID key is programmed into the memory of each individual key and it is specific to the end customer. The protection mechanism used in the standard module is based around an expiry date (stored as ticks) and a GUID used to authenticate supplied activation keys. Activation keys are supplied by Labman to the end user. These keys are supplied in encrypted form. The encryption algorithm used is AES with our unique vendor code used as the encryption seed. Our vender code should never be divulged. These activation keys contain an expiry date and a GUID (unique to the customer). Whenever a valid activation key is supplied it is stored on the HASP keys internal memory. If an expiry date of 0 is encoded in the activation key then this will turn off the expiry date checking (this can be turned back on by supplying another activation key with valid expiry date if required). The standard module contains a helper form (frmHASPHLTimeHelper) which can be used from your project to display a standard dialog box that the user can enter activation keys into. This should be used along with the function blnAuthenticateSoftware. If this function returns FALSE then display this form to the user.

member.name: M:Labman.TraciotTelemetry.AddEventLog(System.Int32,System.String,Traciot.Messages.EventMessage.EventTypes,System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.SortedList{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Adds to the event log. This is useful for logging a particular event (such as failed to cap). This is not intended to log every system log message! This override allows project specific event codes to be logged. Project specific event codes are incremented by 0x1000000 so they stand out from standard codes.
member.param: A unique code for this event that is specific to the project
The event message or description (this will be used as a search key so should be kept generic)
Optional value to add to the event (e.g. a duration for the event etc)
An optional key/value list of meta data to attach to the message (for instance to store the rack position of an event that occurred)
